The '''Heath of the Sky-roof''' was an upland heath located about a [[wikipedia:League (unit)|league]] from the town of [[Tavrobel]] in [[Tol Eressëa]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.

It was the location of a [[Battle of the Heath of the Sky-roof|great battle]] during the [[Faring Forth]], after which it was called the '''''Withered Heath''''', presumably due to the destruction that has taken place during the battle.<ref name="Sky">{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''5''', p. 284</ref>

== Other names ==
The place was also called the '''''High Heath''''', and the '''''Heaven Roof'''''.<ref name="High">{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''8''', p. 287</ref>

Its [[Gnomish]] name was '''''Ladwen-na-Dhaideloth''''',<ref name="High"/> glossed as the "Heath of the Sky-roof", consisting of the elements ''[[ladwen]]'' ("levelness, flatness; plain, heath; plane; surface") + ''[[na (Gnomish word)|na]]'' ("of the") + ''[[dai]]'' ("sky") + ''[[teloth]]'' ("roofing, canopy, shelter").<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-2717600823.html|articlename=G. ''Ladwen-na-Dhaideloth'' loc.|website=Eldamo|accessed=16 April 2022}}</ref> An alternative form of the name was '''''Ladwen Daideloth'''''.<ref name="High"/>

Another name for the place was '''''Dor-na-Dhaideloth''''',<ref name="High"/> meaning "Land of Heaven Roof", the first element of the name being ''[[dôr]]'' ("land, country").<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Paul Strack]]|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-615340087.html|articlename=G. ''Dor-na-Dhaideloth'' loc.|website=Eldamo|accessed=16 April 2022}}</ref>

== Inspiration ==
G. L. Elkin, the Acting Director of the Shugborough Estate, has suggested to [[Christopher Tolkien]] that the Heath of the Sky-roof might have been inspired by Hopton Heath, where in 1643, a [[wikipedia:Battle of Hopton Heath|battle]] of the [[wikipedia:First English Civil War|Civil War]] was fought.

It was located a few miles away from [[wikipedia:Great Haywood|Great Haywood]] which served as an inspiration for Tavrobel.<ref>{{LR|A3}}, p. 413</ref>

Alternatively, according to [[John Garth]], it might have been inspired by [[wikipedia:Cannock Chase|Cannock Chase]], a small area of countryside in [[wikipedia:Staffordshire|Staffordshire]].<ref>[[John Garth]], ''[[Tolkien and the Great War]]'', "Epilogue. 'A new light'", p. 273</ref>
